raw: overridden
overridden
* Specify the methods to use for ascending and descending sorts of a
* particular column.
* @param columnIndex {Integer}
*   The index of the column for which the sort methods are being
*   provided.
* @param compare {Function|Map}
*   If provided as a Function, this is the comparator function to sort in
*   ascending order. It takes three parameters: the two arrays of row data,
*   row1 and row2, being compared and the column index sorting was requested
*   for.
*   For backwards compatability, user-supplied compare functions may still
*   take only two parameters, the two arrays of row data, row1 and row2,
*   being compared and obtain the column index as arguments.callee.columnIndex.
*   This is deprecated, however, as arguments.callee is disallowed in ES5 strict
*   mode and ES6.
*   The comparator function must return 1, 0 or -1, when the column in row1
*   is greater than, equal to, or less than, respectively, the column in
*   row2.
*   If this parameter is a Map, it shall have two properties: "ascending"
*   and "descending". The property value of each is a comparator
*   function, as described above.
*   If only the "ascending" function is provided (i.e. this parameter is
*   a Function, not a Map), then the "descending" function is built
*   dynamically by passing the two parameters to the "ascending" function
*   in reversed order. <i>Use of a dynamically-built "descending" function
*   generates at least one extra function call for each row in the table,
*   and possibly many more. If the table is expected to have more than
*   about 1000 rows, you will likely want to provide a map with a custom
* "descending" sort function as well as the "ascending" one.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Specify the methods to use for ascending and descending sorts of a particular column.

@param.name: @param
@param.description:
The index of the column for which the sort methods are being
   provided.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: compare {Function|Map} If provided as a Function, this is the comparator function to sort in ascending order. It takes three parameters: the two arrays of row data, row1 and row2, being compared and the column index sorting was requested for. For backwards compatability, user-supplied compare functions may still take only two parameters, the two arrays of row data, row1 and row2, being compared and obtain the column index as arguments.callee.columnIndex. This is deprecated, however, as arguments.callee is disallowed in ES5 strict mode and ES6. The comparator function must return 1, 0 or -1, when the column in row1 is greater than, equal to, or less than, respectively, the column in row2. If this parameter is a Map, it shall have two properties: "ascending" and "descending". The property value of each is a comparator function, as described above. If only the "ascending" function is provided (i.e. this parameter is a Function, not a Map), then the "descending" function is built dynamically by passing the two parameters to the "ascending" function in reversed order. Use of a dynamically-built "descending" function generates at least one extra function call for each row in the table, and possibly many more. If the table is expected to have more than about 1000 rows, you will likely want to provide a map with a custom "descending" sort function as well as the "ascending" one.
@param.description: If provided as a Function, this is the comparator function to sort in ascending order. It takes three parameters: the two arrays of row data, row1 and row2, being compared and the column index sorting was requested for. For backwards compatability, user-supplied compare functions may still take only two parameters, the two arrays of row data, row1 and row2, being compared and obtain the column index as arguments.callee.columnIndex. This is deprecated, however, as arguments.callee is disallowed in ES5 strict mode and ES6. The comparator function must return 1, 0 or -1, when the column in row1 is greater than, equal to, or less than, respectively, the column in row2. If this parameter is a Map, it shall have two properties: "ascending" and "descending". The property value of each is a comparator function, as described above. If only the "ascending" function is provided (i.e. this parameter is a Function, not a Map), then the "descending" function is built dynamically by passing the two parameters to the "ascending" function in reversed order. Use of a dynamically-built "descending" function generates at least one extra function call for each row in the table, and possibly many more. If the table is expected to have more than about 1000 rows, you will likely want to provide a map with a custom "descending" sort function as well as the "ascending" one.

raw: * Returns the sortMethod(s) for a table column.

*   The property value of each is a comparator function, as described
*   in {@link #setSortMethods}.

@param.body:
columnIndex {Integer} The index of the column for which the sort
   methods are being  provided.

The index of the column for which the sort
   methods are being  provided.

@return.name: @return
@return.body:
{Map} a map with the two properties "ascending"
   and "descending" for the specified column.
   The property value of each is a comparator function, as described
   in {@link #setSortMethods}.
@return.description:
a map with the two properties "ascending"
   and "descending" for the specified column.
   The property value of each is a comparator function, as described
   in {@link #setSortMethods}.

raw: * Sets rows in the model. The rows overwrite the old rows starting at

*          row-array contains the values in that row in the order of the columns

*          the rows are set from the beginning (0).
